unnormalised: New Delhi, October 26 – Residents of several Indian states, including Uttar Pradesh and Bihar, continue to face scheduled load shedding as the festive season approaches. Power distribution companies (DISCOMs) are struggling to meet peak electricity demand, exacerbated by the ongoing heat wave and increased consumption during Diwali preparations.

unnormalised: Officials at the Central Electricity Authority (CEA) attribute the disruptions to a combination of factors, including coal supply chain bottlenecks and maintenance work at key power generation plants like the NTPC Ramagundam. Dr. Sharma, a leading energy expert, warned that unplanned outages could further strain the already burdened grid.

unnormalised: Power cuts are reportedly lasting between 2 to 4 hours in many areas, impacting businesses and households alike. The Confederation of Indian Industry (CII) has expressed concerns about the economic impact, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Some residents have resorted to using inverters and generators, incurring additional expenses. The cost of a decent inverter setup for a 1000 sq ft apartment now runs upwards of Rs. 20,000. Authorities are urging consumers to conserve electricity and report any instances of unauthorized connections to curb the issue. Further updates are expected from the Ministry of Power by the end of the week.
